授業目的: The purpose of this course is that students will acquire knowledge and understand global development agenda--an important transition from the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and complex implementation aspects of SDGs, which contains 17 goals and 169 targets adopted by the UN's 193 member states in 2015.
到達目標: 1. Students will be able to assess the transition from MDGs to SDGs.2. Students will be able to research major Sustainable Development Goals. 3. Students will be able to understand the policy direction of UN development system at large under and the leadership of Secretary General.
特記事項: 【合併】Global Sustainable Development（総合政策研究科修士）/Global Sustainable Development（大学院共通科目・認定科目前期）
関連科目: UN and Foreign Affairs related courses
授業の概要・背景: This unique course is conducted omnibus by ex and current UN staff to deliver the contents and essences of Sustainable Development Goals from the view point of Leave No One Behind and of different UN organizations. Some of the lectures are based on the real experience and resources of the lecturers. The course will discuss how the global consensus was built, how feasible SDGs may be, what strategies would be used for their achievement, and what are the major stakeholders' interests and their engagement.
授業方法: This course is conducted in a "Face to Face "format. The class will be held in seminar/lecture style. Resource person(s) would encourage students for active class discussion in focusing on selected topics. Students' presentations would be requested in each module. The course will be taught by UN and other international practitioners and experts with hands-on experience in development.

第1回:
【All 14 sessions will be conducted in person】
April 14 Prof. Keiko Nishino
Introduction of resource person(s) and seminar contents: review of the references, requirements, etc., in clarifying the course directions. Group studies are encouraged to prepare presentation and discussion: group work, presentation quality, etc., should be discussed at this orientation session
Enrolled students to prepare to express their expectations of what to focus on and to learn the course.
第2回:
April 21 Prof. Keiko Nishino (Sustainable Development & Leave No One Behind)
In September 2015, all 193 United Nations member states agreed and committed to achieve Sustainable Development Goals by 2030 with the embedded aspiration of leaving no one behind. For this session, we will review the context of Leave No One Behind in the SDGs, present situations and challenges. Who will be left behind in what way?

Students will be asked to read the chapter one and prepare analytical presentations. Homi Kharas, John W. McArthur, and Izumi Ohno (Editors), Leave No One Behind 2020 Brooking Institution Press ISDN 978-0-8157-3783-4
https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/LNOB_Chapter1.pdf
第3回:
April 28 Prof. Makiko Tagashira SDG 8 (Employment, Inclusive Growth)
The UN General Assembly decided to convene the Second World Social Summit for Social Development from 4 to 6 November 2025 in Qatar. The importance of productive employment was addressed at the first Social Summit (1995) and identified as one of the three pillars for achieving social development. Since then, governments and the UN have been working to create an environment that promotes full and productive employment and decent work for all, and since the adoption of the 2030 Agenda, through implementing SDG8. This session will analyze recent global trends in employment, and discuss why advancing SDG 8 is necessary to reduce poverty and inequality and achieve the objectives of the 2030 Agenda.
Reference: UNDESA, The Global Development Goals 2023 and 2024. ILO, World Employment and Social Outlook, Trends 2024.

Assignment:  Read the SG’s report on “Creating full and productive employment and decent work for all as a way of overcoming inequalities to accelerate the recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic and the full implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development” (E/CN.5/2023/3) and prepare a short paper (2 - 3 pages) on “Practical strategies to create productive employment and decent work for all (2 - 3 concrete strategies)”
第4回:
May 12 Prof. Makiko Tagashira SDG 10 (Reduce Inequality)
For the first time, the issue of inequality has been included in the global agenda, namely as a stand-alone goal - SDG 10: Reduce inequality within and among countries. This session will review the recent trends on inequality, highlight the importance of addressing inequality to achieve various SDGs; Discuss existing challenges, and explore possible additional indicators to better capture/address income and non-income inequality.  
Reference:Reference: UNDESA, The Global Development Goals 2023 and 2024. Development Finance International (DFI), OXFAM, Pathfinders, Policy Briefing (June 2023): A CALL TO ACTION TO SAVE SDG10. https://www.development-finance.org/files/SDG10_policy_brief_English.pdf. UNDP, Goal 10: https://www.undp.org/sustainable-development-goals/reduced-inequalities

Assignment:  Read the SG’s report on “Addressing inequalities and challenges to social inclusion through fiscal, wage and social protection policies” (E/CN.5/2019/3) and prepare a short paper (2 – 3 pages) on “Are the current indicators sufficient to achieve SDG 10, what needs to be added?”
第5回:
May 19 Prof. Keio Nishino SDG 4 (Education)
What does quality education mean to all of us? What kind of differences did the world make from MDGs to SDGs? What will be the 21st century education and what is needed to deliver it to all that need? This session will analyze the current situation of global education and try to answer such questions for leaving no children and adults behind from quality education.

Students will be asked to read the  chapter six of the book and other reference materials uploaded in LUNA, and prepare analytical presentations. Homi Kharas, John W. McArthur, and Izumi Ohno (Editors), Leave No One Behind 2020 Brooking Institution Press ISDN 978-0-8157-3783-4
https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/LNOB_Chapter6.pdf
第6回:
May 26 Prof. Keiko Nishino SDG 5 (Gender Equality) 
In this complex and diversified world, "Gender Equality" is discussed and treated in many different local contexts. By reviewing three chapters of "Leave No One Behind", this session will analyze the root causes of gender inequalities, getting out of ultra-poor situations and to include all in financial systems for the underserved population, especially women.

Students will be asked to read the chapters two, three and eight of the book, and prepare analytical presentations. Homi Kharas, John W. McArthur, and Izumi Ohno (Editors), Leave No One Behind 2020 Brooking Institution Press ISDN 978-0-8157-3783-4
Chapter 2: https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/LNOB_Chapter2.pdf
Chapter 3: https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/LNOB_Chapter3.pdf
Chapter 8: https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/LNOB_Chapter8.pdf
第7回:
June 2 Prof. Rintaro Mori SDG 3 (Health System and Governance)
The session discusses how health has become the major agenda item in global diplomacy and introduces the architecture around the health system, including its six building blocks (Leadership and governance, Service delivery, Health system financing, Health workforce, Medical products, vaccines and technologies, and Health information systems), with a particular focus on health governance.

Students will be asked to prepare analytical presentations for assigned blocks based on the following materials:
World Health Organization (WHO). Everybody's business - strengthening health systems to improve health outcomes: WHO's framework for action. WHO; Geneva: 2007. (https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/everybody-s-business----strengthening-health-systems-to-improve-health-outcomes)
第8回:
June 9 Prof. Rintaro Mori SDG 3 (Women's and Children's Health and Wellbeing)
The session discusses how the women's and children's health agenda has transformed amid the emerging population (population ageing and low fertility) and epidemiological (communicable to non-communicable diseases) transition.

Students are required to read through the report below before the lecture: Protect the Promise: 2022 Progress Report on the Every Woman Every Child Global Strategy For Women’s, Children’s and Adolescents’ Health (2016–2030). World Health Organization, United Nations Children’s Fund 2022. (https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240060104)
第9回:
June 16 Prof. Yasumitu Doken SDG 16 (Peace Justice and Strong Institutions)  
SDG 16 seeks to promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice for all, and build effective, accountable, and inclusive institutions. This session will review the progress made toward this goal, analyze its interlinkages with other SDGs, and discuss the challenges and opportunities it presents. Participants will also explore practical examples of initiatives, with a focus on how UNDP projects are contributing to the advancement of SDG 16.

Students are required to read the materials listed below, select one indicator of SDG 16 and prepare to make a brief presentation on their chosen indicator before the session: UN SDG16 Overview and Targets, Global Progress Report on Sustainable Development Goal 16 Indicators;  and 2nd Global Progress Report on SDG 16 Indicators
第10回:
June 23 Prof. Yasumitu Doken SDG 1 (Poverty Reduction)
This session will explore global efforts to achieve SDG 1, with a focus on the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) as a tool to address poverty. Using Afghanistan as a case study, it will review UNDP’s initiatives as concrete examples of advancing this goal. Participants will gain insights into challenges, opportunities, and practical approaches to eradicating poverty.

Students are required to read the following materials before the session: UN SDG 1 Overview and Targets (Official UN SDG 1 Page); UNDP SDG 1 confidential Consigning poverty to history; and 2024 Global Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)- Poverty amid conflict. After the session, students are asked to prepare a short paper (3-5 pages) discussing the key challenges that the international community currently faces in advancing SDG 1 in Afghanistan.
第11回:
June 30 Mr. Paul Rosenberg SDG 11 (Disaster Risk Prevention)
This session explores the interconnectedness between disaster risk and sustainable development, recognizing the bidirectional relationship where disasters can derail development progress, and unsustainable development can exacerbate disaster risks. Key topics include the human and economic costs of disasters, the links between disaster vulnerability and broader poverty and development challenges, and the importance of risk-informed development planning and investment. The session will also examine how climate change amplifies disaster risks in development contexts and how addressing disaster risk is essential for achieving sustainable urbanization under SDG 11.

UNDRR. (2015). Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030. (Available at: https://www.undrr.org/publication/sendai-framework-disaster-risk-reduction-2015-2030)

Global Facility for Disaster Reduction and Recovery (GFDRR). (2016). Building Back Better: Achieving Resilience through Stronger, Faster, and More Inclusive Post-Disaster Reconstruction. (Available at: https://www.gfdrr.org/en/publication/building-back-better)
第12回:
July 7 Mr. Paul Rosenberg SDG 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities)
This session examines urban sustainability in a broad context, focusing on the core principles of sustainable urban development and the challenges posed by rapid urbanization in developing countries. We will explore how cities can plan and deliver infrastructure and essential services in ways that support both environmental health and social equity.

Assigned Readings

1. WHO (2016). Global Report on Urban Health: Equitable, Healthier Cities for Sustainable Development

Link: https://unhabitat.org/global-report-on-urban-health-equitable-healthier-cities-for-sustainable-development

2. UN-Habitat (2020). World Cities Report 2020: The Value of Sustainable Urbanization

Link: https://unhabitat.org/world-cities-report-2020-the-value-of-sustainable-urbanization
第13回:
July 14 Prof. Keiko Nishino: (Monitoring the progress of SDGs, VNRs and other systems)
How are the progress of SDGs monitored? One instrument is a Voluntary National Review regularly conducted by the member states. These national reviews are expected to serve as a basis for the regular reviews by the high-level political forum (HLPF), meeting under the auspices of ECOSOC. The voluntary national reviews (VNRs) aim to facilitate the sharing of experiences, including successes, challenges and lessons learned, with a view to accelerating the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. In this session, we will use the VNR and other monitoring tools to review the progress and challenges for achiving the SDGs.
Students are asked to read the 2024 VNR Synthesis Report, choose one country VNR and present the progress. https://hlpf.un.org/sites/default/files/2024-11/VNR%202024%20Synthesis%20Report.pdf

Wrap up this session by clarifying the contents of Sustainable Development Goals, especially from the point of Leaving No One Behind.
